sols_html:
Recall up to this point that Bob computed \(\displaystyle C \equiv P^{e} \mod{n}\) and you’ve computed a d such that \(\displaystyle ed \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(n)}\) so in fact, we have \(\displaystyle ed = 1 + \phi(n)s\) for some integer s. Using Euler’s Theorem, we can compute P back if we compute

\(\displaystyle C^{d} \equiv (P^{e})^{d} \equiv P^{ed} \equiv P^{1 + \phi(n)s} \equiv P(P^{\phi(n)})^{s} \equiv P \mod{n}\).

This is computable since Alice has both C and d available to her. This completes the proof.
